BeeChallenges: There is a need for more inspectors in order to keep up with everything they have to do (Time).

The general public has taken on "save the bees" initiative, but discussion is focused on neonicotinoides and needs to be broadened. Beekeeping hobbyists are not well informed because no mandated registration means no funding for state program or University programs (education).
Adequately surveying all bees coming into and leaving the state (time).
Beekeepers tend to be reclusive which hinders registration initiative.

InspectorTitle: Program Manager, Plant Protection and Weed Control, Kansas Department of Agriculture
BeeChallenges: Only responsibility is to inspect exports. No inspection program in Kansas.
RegistrationExplanation: Registration no longer mandatory due to absence of Apiary Inspection Program

BeeChallenges: Making enough time to get around to inspect everyone who needs to be inspected.

InspectorTitle: Chief Apiary Inspector and State Apiarist
BeeChallenges: Cybil wishes she had more time to teach beekeeping hobbyists. Hobbyists are eager for more mentorship and education.

Michael Hansen states he is limited in his (time) as State Apiarist due to his many other responsibilities and the absence of an inspection program and funding. He is concerned about the ability of recreational beekeepers to recognize common diseases such as foul brood. Michigan has an intense need for healthy honey bees because more than 60 of their 300 annual crops require bee pollination. Michigan bees also significantly aid pollination efforts in California, Georgia, Florida, and across the country. For such reasons, Michigan would greatly benefit from an Apiary Inspection Program.
RegistrationExplanation: No program to register with. Registration mandate repealled 1993.

InspectorTitle: Export Certification & Animal Damage Compensation Program Coordinator
BeeChallenges: The change in requirements for USDA sampling caused complications in spring 2018. Geographically large state makes it difficult for single inspector to get surveys ( for National Honey Bee Survey and exports) finished-time.
RegistrationExplanation: No program to register with. Registration mandate repealled 2006.

BeeChallenges: There is only one part-time inspector and only around 2-3 dozen inspections are done every year. The only inspections he has time to conduct are for bees that are being exported out of state.
Tim is the only inspector, which means he has to prioritize beekeepers to visit. Varroa cause the most damage to colonies in the state.

Paul Cappy stated that increased cooperation with beekeeper hobbyists (of which there are around 3,000 to 4,000 in NY) is needed in order to maintain bee health across the state. The problem with American foulbrood is increasing and registering beekeeping hobbyists would help control outbreaks.
European foulbrood and a new bacterial situation with varroa keeps the inspectors busy.
Floral diversity has decreased while varroa density has increased, resulting in overall compromised bee health across the state. Education opportunities have increased in the past years, however.
Encouraging people to conduct appropriate checks for varroa has been Joey's biggest problem. There is a lack of education for hobbyists.

There has been an increase in hobbyists and people raising bees for the purpose of selling them. Keith has been constantly traveling in order to visit the hives that need inspecting. The problem varroa cause is consistantly growing, which has led to an increase in the frequency that Keith comes across all diseases. Last winter was the worst in terms of hive loss that Kieth has seen in many years.
